Dialogue.Student: Hi, I'm Emily Johnson. I'm a 23-year-old studying psychology.
Dialogue.Counselor: Hello, Emily! It's nice to meet you. How are you feeling today?
Dialogue.Student: Thanks! I'm feeling excited but also a bit anxious about the new semester.
Dialogue.Counselor: That’s completely normal! Starting a new semester can bring a mix of emotions. What aspects are making you feel anxious?
Dialogue.Student: I’ve noticed that some of my classmates are really outgoing, and it makes me self-conscious about being introverted.
Dialogue.Counselor: I see. It can be tough when you compare yourself to others. How has this affected your thoughts about connecting with your classmates?
Dialogue.Student: I worry that I won’t be able to make meaningful connections as an introvert.
Dialogue.Counselor: It’s understandable to feel that way, but being an introvert can also bring unique strengths to your relationships. Have you thought about small steps to connect with others?
Dialogue.Student: I guess I could try to engage in smaller groups or one-on-one conversations.
Dialogue.Counselor: That sounds like a great idea! Building connections gradually might ease some of that anxiety. Remember, it’s okay to be yourself.

Dialogue.Student: Hi again. I'm feeling a bit more isolated lately. I tried to participate in group projects, but I often feel overlooked.
Dialogue.Counselor: I'm sorry to hear that, Emily. Can you share more about what happened in those group projects?
Dialogue.Student: In a recent discussion, I attempted to contribute, but I got interrupted, and it discouraged me.
Dialogue.Counselor: That sounds frustrating. It’s hard to feel heard, especially when you’re trying to express your ideas. How did that make you feel?
Dialogue.Student: It made me feel vulnerable and like I don’t belong.
Dialogue.Counselor: It's okay to feel vulnerable. It shows you're navigating new social dynamics. Have you talked to your roommate, Sarah, about how you're feeling?
Dialogue.Student: I did, and she was supportive. But I still have this lingering fear that I won’t fit in.
Dialogue.Counselor: Having someone like Sarah to talk to is valuable. It might help to focus on the qualities that make you unique and bring value to your group.

Dialogue.Student: Hello again. I joined a study group recently, hoping it would help me feel more integrated, but I struggled to share my thoughts.
Dialogue.Counselor: That sounds challenging. What made you feel hesitant in the study group?
Dialogue.Student: I felt anxious about being judged and often found it hard to voice my opinions.
Dialogue.Counselor: It’s completely normal to feel anxious in new group settings. Have you had any experiences in the past that were similar?
Dialogue.Student: Yes, I often feel this way in social situations.
Dialogue.Counselor: It’s good to recognize this pattern. Building confidence takes time. Maybe you can prepare some thoughts before meetings to help ease your anxiety.
Dialogue.Student: That sounds helpful. I just wish I could be more relatable.
Dialogue.Counselor: You are more relatable than you think! Everyone has their own uniqueness to bring to the table. Try to focus on your strengths during discussions.

Dialogue.Student: Hi, I’ve had a rough week. I overheard some classmates making jokes about introverted students.
Dialogue.Counselor: I'm really sorry to hear that, Emily. How did that make you feel?
Dialogue.Student: It triggered a lot of emotions in me—anger, hurt, and I feel so disconnected.
Dialogue.Counselor: Feeling hurt from such comments is completely valid. It's tough to hear negative remarks about something so personal.
Dialogue.Student: I wanted to speak up, but I held back out of fear of rejection.
Dialogue.Counselor: It’s a challenging position to be in. Sometimes, addressing those situations can be powerful, but it’s also okay to take your time to process your feelings.
Dialogue.Student: I decided to write in my journal to process everything.
Dialogue.Counselor: That's a great coping strategy! Journaling can help you clarify your feelings. Just remember, you’re not defined by others’ perceptions of you.
Dialogue.Student: Thank you for the support. I will try to focus on that.
